greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = Least i > 1, such that 2n+1 = 2*A000040(i)+A000040(k) for some k>1, 0 if no such i exists.
example: For n < 4 there are no such primes, thus a(1)-a(3)=0. For n=4, 2*4+1 = 9 = 2*3+3 and 3=A000040(2), thus a(4)=2. For n=7, 2*7+1 = 15 = 2*5+5 and 5=A000040(3), thus a(7)=3.
mathematica: Do[m = 3; While[ ! (PrimeQ[m] && ((n - 2*m) > 2) && PrimeQ[n - 2*m]), m = m + 2]; k = PrimePi[m]; Print[k], {n, 9, 299, 2}]
program: (Scheme, with Aubrey Jaffer's SLIB Scheme library from http://www.swiss.ai.mit.edu/~jaffer/SLIB.html )
(define (A103507 n) (let loop ((i 2)) (let ((p1 (A000040 i))) (cond ((>= p1 n) 0) ((prime? (+ 1 (* 2 (- n p1)))) i) (else (loop (+ 1 i)))))))
xref: a(n) = A049084(A103153(n)), for n >= 4. Can be used to compute A103153 and A103508. Cf. A103509.
results.author: _Lei Zhou_, Feb 09 2005
ext: Edited, Scheme-code added and starting offset changed from 0 to 1 by _Antti Karttunen_, Jun 19 2007
